nodes.priorLine: Ask: “I need access to the shack.”
nodes.lineToEdit:
Access is not a single action. It’s a chain of custody.
If you mean “entry,” entry is governed by the site’s mothball status, which is—just to be clear—an operational posture, not abandonment.
nodes.nextLine:
So the correct first step is to confirm whether the access control is functional enough to produce a record.
Try your badge. If it fails, don’t repeat it more than twice. Repetition implies expectation, and expectation implies a test.
Tests imply scope.
nodes.revisedLine:

Authentication creates a timestamp. Actuation creates liability.

nodes.nextLine:
Stable in the sense of “not moving.” Not stable in the sense of “safe.” Different column.
Assurance is remote. Contracted by your funders, not your office—just so we don’t muddle authority.
I document deviations. I don’t authorize solutions.

nodes.lineToEdit:
I hear you, and I’m not disputing your badge color.
But “actual access path” implies there is one sanctioned route, and if I say it out loud, it becomes discoverable.

There is no on-site attendant. There is no remote door release.
The reader is budgeted to log attempts, not to drive the strike. That’s why it’s “intermittently energized.”
If you need entry, you’ll need a different mechanism than the reader.

nodes.priorLine:
There’s no one to answer.
But the Finding Slip has a “Liaison Notes” section, written in a voice that expects compliance.
nodes.lineToEdit:
For closure purposes, we need a comparable event category.
I’m not saying it is an incident. I’m saying if it were treated as one, the documentation trail would be defensible.
And defensible is the point. Not dramatic. Not… creative.
nodes.nextLine:
You can resolve this in one of three ways, which is generous, frankly:
1) Attach an incident page. A plain narrative. What happened, what you observed, what you did. No speculation.
2) Attach a waiver. Someone with authority accepts the residual risk. Not you. Not me.
3) Attach a no-anomaly test printout from Operations. If Ops can certify nothing anomalous occurred during a controlled run, the finding downgrades to “documentation variance.”
Which is a real category. It exists in the framework. That’s what we need.

Not dramatic. (pause)
Not… creative.

nodes.priorLine: ask: “Comparable to what?”
nodes.lineToEdit:
Exactly. That’s the issue.
If you tell me it’s comparable to a reflection event, I can anchor it to prior guidance.
If you tell me it’s comparable to equipment drift, I can anchor it to calibration controls.
If you tell me it’s comparable to a near-miss, I can anchor it to safety reporting.
I’m not asking you to be poetic. I’m asking you to pick the least-wrong shelf.
nodes.nextLine: And if I don’t.
nodes.revisedLine:
Exactly. That’s the issue. (pause)
Tell me it matches a reflection event. (pause)
Then I anchor it to prior guidance. (pause)
Tell me it matches equipment drift. (pause)
Then I anchor it to calibration controls. (pause)
Tell me it matches a near-miss. (pause)
Then I anchor it to safety reporting. (pause)
I’m not asking for poetry. (pause)
Pick the least-wrong shelf.
